1.20: The youth and the old man lie On the ground in the streets; My virgins and my young men Are fallen by the sword; Thou hast slain them in the day of Thine anger; Thou hast slaughtered unsparingly.
1.21: Thou hast called, as in the day of a solemn assembly, My terrors on every side, And there was none in the day of the LORD’S anger That escaped or remained; Those that I have dandled and brought up Hath mine enemy consumed.’
1.1: The Lord hath swallowed up unsparingly All the habitations of Jacob; He hath thrown down in His wrath The strongholds of the daughter of Judah; He hath brought them down to the ground; He hath profaned the kingdom and the princes thereof.
1.0: How hath the Lord covered with a cloud The daughter of Zion in His anger! He hath cast down from heaven unto the earth The beauty of Israel, And hath not remembered His footstool In the day of His anger.
1.3: He hath bent His bow like an enemy, Standing with His right hand as an adversary, And hath slain all that were pleasant to the eye; In the tent of the daughter of Zion He hath poured out His fury like fire.
1.2: He hath cut off in fierce anger All the horn of Israel; He hath drawn back His right hand From before the enemy; And He hath burned in Jacob like a flaming fire, Which devoureth round about.
1.5: And He hath stripped His tabernacle, as if it were a garden, He hath destroyed His place of assembly; The LORD hath caused to be forgotten in Zion Appointed season and sabbath, And hath rejected in the indignation of His anger The king and the priest.
1.4: The Lord is become as an enemy, He hath swallowed up Israel; He hath swallowed up all her palaces, He hath destroyed his strongholds; And He hath multiplied in the daughter of Judah Mourning and moaning.
1.7: The LORD hath purposed to destroy The wall of the daughter of Zion; He hath stretched out the line, He hath not withdrawn His hand from destroying; But He hath made the rampart and wall to mourn, They languish together.
1.6: The Lord hath cast off His altar, He hath abhorred His sanctuary, He hath given up into the hand of the enemy The walls of her palaces; They have made a noise in the house of the LORD, As in the day of a solemn assembly.
1.9: They sit upon the ground, and keep silence, The elders of the daughter of Zion; They have cast up dust upon their heads, They have girded themselves with sackcloth; The virgins of Jerusalem hang down Their heads to the ground.
1.8: Her gates are sunk into the ground; He hath destroyed and broken her bars; Her king and her princes are among the nations, Instruction is no more; Yea, her prophets find No vision from the LORD.
1.11: They say to their mothers: ‘Where is corn and wine?’ When they swoon as the wounded In the broad places of the city, When their soul is poured out Into their mothers’bosom.
1.10: Mine eyes do fail with tears, Mine inwards burn, My liver is poured upon the earth, For the breach of the daughter of my people; Because the young children and the sucklings swoon In the broad places of the city.
1.13: Thy prophets have seen visions for thee Of vanity and delusion; And they have not uncovered thine iniquity, To bring back thy captivity; But have prophesied for thee burdens Of vanity and seduction.
1.12: What shall I take to witness for thee? What shall I liken to thee, O daughter of Jerusalem? What shall I equal to thee, that I may comfort thee, O virgin daughter of Zion? For thy breach is great like the sea; Who can heal thee?
1.15: All thine enemies have opened Their mouth wide against thee; They hiss and gnash the teeth; They say: ‘We have swallowed her up; Certainly this is the day that we looked for; We have found, we have seen it.’
1.14: All that pass by clap Their hands at thee; They hiss and wag their head At the daughter of Jerusalem: ‘Is this the city that men called The perfection of beauty, The joy of the whole earth?’ .
1.17: Their heart cried unto the Lord: ‘O wall of the daughter of Zion, Let tears run down like a river Day and night; Give thyself no respite; Let not the apple of thine eye cease.
1.16: The LORD hath done that which He devised; He hath performed His word That He commanded in the days of old; He hath thrown down unsparingly; And He hath caused the enemy to rejoice over thee, He hath exalted the horn of thine adversaries.
1.19: ’See, O LORD, and consider, To whom Thou hast done thus! Shall the women eat their fruit, The children that are dandled in the hands? Shall the priest and the prophet be slain In the sanctuary of the Lord?
1.18: Arise, cry out in the night, At the beginning of the watches; Pour out thy heart like water Before the face of the Lord; Lift up thy hands toward Him For the life of thy young children, That faint for hunger At the head of every street.’

0.20: They have heard how I sigh, [and] there is none to comfort me, all my enemies have heard of my trouble [and] are glad that You have done it; [if only] You had brought the day that You proclaimed [upon them] and let them be like me.
0.21: May all their wickedness come before You, and deal with them as You have dealt with me for all my transgressions, for my sighs are many and my heart is faint.
0.1: She weeps, yea, she weeps in the night, and her tears are on her cheek; she has no comforter among all her lovers; all her friends have betrayed her; they have become her enemies.
0.0: O how has the city that was once so populous remained lonely! She has become like a widow! She that was great among the nations, a princess among the provinces, has become tributary.
0.3: The roads of Zion are mournful because no one comes to the appointed season; all her gates are desolate, her priests moan; her maidens grieve while she herself suffers bitterly.
0.2: Judah went into exile because of affliction and great servitude; she settled among the nations, [and] found no rest; all her pursuers overtook her between the boundaries.
0.5: And gone is from the daughter of Zion all her splendor; her princes were like harts who did not find pasture and they departed without strength before [their] pursuer.
0.4: Her adversaries have become the head, her enemies are at ease; for the Lord has afflicted her because of the multitude of her sins; her young children went into captivity before the enemy. (PAUSE FOR REFLECTIONS)
0.7: Jerusalem sinned grievously, therefore she became a wanderer; all who honored her despised her, for they have seen her shame; moreover, she herself sighed and turned away.
0.6: Jerusalem recalls the days of her poverty and her miseries, [and] all her precious things that were from days of old; when her people fell into the hand of the adversary, and there was none to help her; the enemies gazed, gloating on her desolation.
0.9: The adversary stretched forth his hand upon all her precious things, for she saw nations enter her Sanctuary, whom You did command not to enter into Your assembly.
0.8: Her uncleanliness is in her skirts, she was not mindful of her end, and she fell astonishingly with none to comfort her. 'Behold, O Lord, my affliction, for the enemy has magnified himself.'
0.11: All of you who pass along the road, let it not happen to you. Behold and see, if there is any pain like my pain, which has been dealt to me, [with] which the Lord saddened [me] on the day of His fierce anger.
0.10: All her people are sighing [as] they search for bread; they gave away their treasures for food to revive the soul; see, O Lord, and behold, how I have become worthless.
0.13: The yoke of my transgressions was marked in His hand, they have become interwoven; they have come upon my neck and caused my strength to fail; the Lord delivered me into the hands of those I could not withstand.
0.12: From above He has hurled fire into my bones, and it broke them; He has spread a net for my feet, He has turned me back, He has made me desolate [and] faint all day long.
0.15: For these things I weep; my eye, yea my eye, sheds tears, for the comforter to restore my soul is removed from me; my children are desolate, for the enemy has prevailed.
0.14: The Lord has trampled all my mighty men in my midst, He summoned an assembly against me to crush my young men; the Lord has trodden as in a wine press the virgin daughter of Judah.
0.17: The Lord is righteous, for I have rebelled against His word; hear, I pray, all you peoples, and behold my pain; my maidens and my youths have gone into captivity.
0.16: Zion spreads out her hands [for help], but there is none to comfort her; the Lord has commanded concerning Jacob [that] his adversaries shall be round about him; Jerusalem has become an outcast among them.
0.19: Behold, O Lord, for I am in distress, my innards burn, my heart is turned within me, for I have grievously rebelled; in the street the sword bereaves, in the house it is like death.
0.18: I called to my lovers, [but] they deceived me; my priests and elders perished in the city, when they sought food for themselves to revive their souls.

3.20: Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom, That dwellest in the land of Uz: The cup shall pass over unto thee also; Thou shalt be drunken, and shalt make thyself naked.
3.21: The punishment of thine iniquity is accomplished, O daughter of Zion, He will no more carry thee away into captivity; He will punish thine iniquity, O daughter of Edom, He will uncover thy sins.
3.1: The precious sons of Zion, Comparable to fine gold, How are they esteemed as earthen pitchers, The work of the hands of the potter!
3.0: How is the gold become dim! How is the most fine gold changed! The hallowed stones are poured out At the head of every street.
3.3: The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth To the roof of his mouth for thirst; The young children ask bread, And none breaketh it unto them.
3.2: Even the jackals draw out the breast, They give suck to their young ones; The daughter of my people is become cruel, Like the ostriches in the wilderness.
3.5: For the iniquity of the daughter of my people is greater Than the sin of Sodom, That was overthrown as in a moment, And no hands fell upon her.
3.4: They that did feed on dainties Are desolate in the streets; They that were brought up in scarlet Embrace dunghills.
3.7: Their visage is blacker than a coal; They are not known in the streets; Their skin is shrivelled upon their bones; It is withered, it is become like a stick.
3.6: Her princes were purer than snow, They were whiter than milk, They were more ruddy in body than rubies, Their polishing was as of sapphire;
3.9: The hands of women full of compassion Have sodden their own children; They were their food In the destruction of the daughter of my people.
3.8: They that are slain with the sword are better Than they that are slain with hunger; For these pine away, stricken through, For want of the fruits of the field.
3.11: The kings of the earth believed not, Neither all the inhabitants of the world, That the adversary and the enemy would enter Into the gates of Jerusalem.
3.10: The LORD hath accomplished His fury, He hath poured out His fierce anger; And He hath kindled a fire in Zion, Which hath devoured the foundations thereof.
3.13: They wander as blind men in the streets, They are polluted with blood, So that men cannot Touch their garments.
3.12: It is because of the sins of her prophets, And the iniquities of her priests, That have shed the blood of the just In the midst of her.
3.15: The anger of the LORD hath divided them; He will no more regard them; They respected not the persons of the priests, They were not gracious unto the elders.
3.14: ’Depart ye! unclean! ’ men cried unto them, ‘Depart, depart, touch not’; Yea, they fled away and wandered; Men said among the nations: ‘They shall no more sojourn here.’
3.17: They hunt our steps, That we cannot go in our broad places; Our end is near, our days are fulfilled; For our end is come.
3.16: As for us, our eyes do yet fail For our vain help; In our watching we have watched For a nation that could not save.
3.19: The breath of our nostrils, the anointed of the LORD, Was taken in their pits; Of whom we said: ‘Under his shadow We shall live among the nations.’
3.18: Our pursuers were swifter Than the eagles of the heaven; They chased us upon the mountains, They lay in wait for us in the wilderness.

2.56: Thou drewest near in the day that I called upon Thee; Thou saidst: ‘Fear not.’ .
2.54: I called upon Thy name, O LORD, Out of the lowest dungeon.
2.42: Thou hast covered with anger and pursued us; Thou hast slain unsparingly.
2.48: Mine eye is poured out, and ceaseth not, Without any intermission,
2.43: Thou hast covered Thyself with a cloud, So that no prayer can pass through.
2.60: Thou hast heard their taunt, O LORD, And all their devices against me;
2.61: The lips of those that rose up against me, And their muttering against me all the day.
2.62: Behold Thou their sitting down, and their rising up; I am their song.
2.63: Thou wilt render unto them a recompense, O LORD, According to the work of their hands.
2.64: Thou wilt give them hardness of heart, Thy curse unto them.
2.49: Till the LORD look forth, And behold from heaven.
2.52: They have cut off my life in the dungeon, And have cast stones upon me.
2.53: Waters flowed over my head; I said: ‘I am cut off.’
2.24: The LORD is good unto them that wait for Him, To the soul that seeketh Him.
2.25: It is good that a man should quietly wait For the salvation of the LORD.
2.26: It is good for a man that he bear The yoke in his youth.
2.27: Let him sit alone and keep silence, Because He hath laid it upon him.
2.20: This I recall to my mind, Therefore have I hope.
2.21: Surely the LORD’S mercies are not consumed, Surely His compassions fail not.
2.22: They are new every morning; Great is Thy faithfulness.
2.23: ’The LORD is my portion’, saith my soul; ‘Therefore will I hope in Him.’
2.46: Terror and the pit are come upon us, Desolation and destruction.
2.47: Mine eye runneth down with rivers of water, For the breach of the daughter of my people.
2.44: Thou hast made us as the offscouring and refuse In the midst of the peoples.
2.45: All our enemies have opened their mouth Wide against us.
2.28: Let him put his mouth in the dust, If so be there may be hope.
2.29: Let him give his cheek to him that smiteth him Let him be filled full with reproach.
2.40: Let us lift up our heart with our hands Unto God in the heavens.
2.41: We have transgressed and have rebelled; Thou hast not pardoned.
2.1: He hath led me and caused me to walk in darkness and not in light.
2.0: I am the man that hath seen affliction By the rod of His wrath.
2.3: My flesh and my skin hath He worn out; He hath broken my bones.
2.2: Surely against me He turneth His hand again and again all the day.
2.5: He hath made me to dwell in dark places, As those that have been long dead. .
2.4: He hath builded against me, and compassed me With gall and travail.
2.7: Yea, when I cry and call for help, He shutteth out my prayer.
2.6: He hath hedged me about, that I cannot go forth; He hath made my chain heavy.
2.9: He is unto me as a bear lying in wait, As a lion in secret places.
2.8: He hath enclosed my ways with hewn stone, He hath made my paths crooked.
2.51: They have chased me sore like a bird, That are mine enemies without cause.
2.39: Let us search and try our ways, And return to the LORD.
2.65: Thou wilt pursue them in anger, and destroy them From under the heavens of the LORD.
2.38: Wherefore doth a living man complain, A strong man because of his sins?
2.59: Thou hast seen all their vengeance And all their devices against me.
2.58: O LORD, Thou hast seen my wrong; Judge Thou my cause.
2.11: He hath bent His bow, and set me As a mark for the arrow.
2.10: He hath turned aside my ways, and pulled me in pieces; He hath made me desolate.
2.13: I am become a derision to all my people, And their song all the day.
2.12: He hath caused the arrows of His quiver To enter into my reins.
2.15: He hath also broken my teeth with gravel stones, He hath made me to wallow in ashes.
2.14: He hath filled me with bitterness, He hath sated me with wormwood.
2.17: And I said: ‘My strength is perished, And mine expectation from the LORD.’
2.16: And my soul is removed far off from peace, I forgot prosperity.
2.19: My soul hath them still in remembrance, And is bowed down within me.
2.18: Remember mine affliction and mine anguish, The wormwood and the gall.
2.31: For though He cause grief, yet will He have compassion According to the multitude of His mercies.
2.30: For the Lord will not cast off For ever.
2.37: Out of the mouth of the Most High proceedeth not Evil and good?
2.36: Who is he that saith, and it cometh to pass, When the Lord commandeth it not?
2.35: To subvert a man in his cause, The Lord approveth not.
2.34: To turn aside the right of a man Before the face of the Most High,
2.33: To crush under foot All the prisoners of the earth,
2.55: Thou heardest my voice; hide not Thine ear at my sighing, at my cry.
2.32: For He doth not afflict willingly, Nor grieve the children of men.
2.57: O Lord, Thou hast pleaded the causes of my soul; Thou hast redeemed my life.
2.50: Mine eye affected my soul, Because of all the daughters of my city.

4.20: Turn Thou us unto Thee, O LORD, and we shall be turned; Renew our days as of old.
4.21:
Thou canst not have utterly rejected us, And be exceeding wroth against us!
[Turn us unto Thee, O Lord, and we shall be turned; Renew our days as of old.]
4.1: Our inheritance is turned unto strangers, Our houses unto aliens.
4.0: Remember, O LORD, what is come upon us; Behold, and see our reproach.
4.3: We have drunk our water for money; Our wood cometh to us for price.
4.2: We are become orphans and fatherless, Our mothers are as widows.
4.5: We have given the hand to Egypt, And to Assyria, to have bread enough;
4.4: To our very necks we are pursued; We labour, and have no rest.
4.7: Servants rule over us; There is none to deliver us out of their hand.
4.6: Our fathers have sinned, and are not; And we have borne their iniquities.
4.9: Our skin is hot like an oven Because of the burning heat of famine.
4.8: We get our bread with the peril of our lives Because of the sword of the wilderness.
4.11: Princes are hanged up by their hand; The faces of elders are not honoured.
4.10: They have ravished the women in Zion, The maidens in the cities of Judah.
4.13: The elders have ceased from the gate, The young men from their music.
4.12: The young men have borne the mill, And the children have stumbled under the wood.
4.15: The crown is fallen from our head; Woe unto us! for we have sinned.
4.14: The joy of our heart is ceased; Our dance is turned into mourning.
4.17: For the mountain of Zion, which is desolate, The foxes walk upon it.
4.16: For this our heart is faint, For these things our eyes are dim;
4.19: Wherefore dost Thou forget us for ever, And forsake us so long time?
4.18: Thou, O LORD, art enthroned for ever, Thy throne is from generation to generation.
